text: Welcome to howtocookthat.net.
I'm Ann Reardon.

For a printable copy of this recipe with all
the ingredient quantities go to the website
at howtocookthat.net.

Today we're making a meringue cake which is
a bit like a Pavlova dressed up.

It has rings or circles of meringue and then
it's filled with cream and fruit.

To start with, whip together your egg whites,
sugar and cream of tartar, you need to keep

whipping them until they are firm enough that
you can hold the bowl upside down without
them falling out.

Place this mixture into a piping bag which
has either a circle attachment or just leave

it as just the bag without any attachment
at all.

Then what you want to do is pipe four large
circles.

Now I've turned the saucer upside down onto
my non-stick paper and drawn the circles to
make it easier.

Make sure you either pipe inside your circles
or just outside your circle so that each of
them is exactly the same.

Bake your circles at 93 degrees centigrade
or 200 degrees Fahrenheit for about 45 minutes.

You don't want them to brown, you just want
them to dry out.

Then take one of your circles, gently peel
it off your non-stick paper.

I'm using non-stick baking paper not grease
proof paper.

Place one of your circles down on a fresh
sheet of paper and pipe a circle of meringue

over the top, then take another of your baked
circles and gently place it on top.

Repeat this process until you've finished
stacking all of your four meringue rings on
top of each other.

If one of them breaks, it doesn't matter because
it's gonna be covered anyway.

So do a circle of meringue and just place
your pieces into place and hopefully they
don't all break for you.
If one or two of them do, it doesn't matter.

Just place them in place and then top with
meringue.

Now we're going to use the rest of our meringue
mixture to cover the cake and to make a smooth
edge on it and on the top of it.

To help get a smooth straight edge, I use
a clean L-shaped ruler.

Place one edge flat on your tray and then
run the other side along the edge of your

cake so that you end up with a straight smooth
edge on your cake.

It's not gonna be perfect because it's meringue,
we're not talking fondant or anything here,
but just get it as good as you can.

Place the rest of your meringue mixture into
a piping bag with a star-shaped nozzle and

pipe a border around the top edge and around
the base of your cake just to make it look
pretty.

Bake it in the oven again at 93 degrees centigrade
for about 45 minutes, start checking it after

half an hour because you don't want it to
go brown, you want that white look to your
cake.

Then very carefully transfer it to your cake
platter.

I like to move the tray over to where I want
it and pull your baking paper underneath the

tray and gently use, as you pulling it, gently
slide the cake off onto your platter.

If a little bit breaks off, don't panic, you
can just put it back on using your ruler icing
as glue and glue it into place.

Next make your roll icing by whipping together
your egg whites and icing sugar until very

stiff and place that in a piping bag and then
we are going to pipe some details onto the
edge of our cake.

I'm simply piping some swirls up and down
then turning the cake and repeating the same
pattern around the cake.

Once you are finished doing that we are going
to use our purple royal icing.

Just make some little flowers to provide a
bit of contrast on the side of our cake and

place one of your silver icing bowls in the
center of that.

Place your cream in a mixing bowl and whisk
it until it is firm.

You don't want to over beat it or you'll make
butter.

Once it's firm then fold through your fruit
of choice and your grated chocolate, if you

are using chocolate and then carefully pour
it down the center of your cake to fill it
right up to the top.

Take some of the fruit that you set aside
and place it on top of your cake to decorate.

I upload new videos each week; make sure you
click to subscribe to be notified when new
videos come out.
